sections.title: What Are Proportional Relationships?

introduction.hook: Have you ever noticed that if you buy 2 candy bars instead of 1, you pay exactly twice as much? That's a proportional relationship in action!
introduction.overview: A proportional relationship is when two things are connected in a very special way: when one thing doubles, the other doubles too. When one thing triples, the other triples too. They always grow (or shrink) together at the same rate.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Two quantities have a proportional relationship when you can always multiply one by the SAME number to get the other.
key_concepts.real_world_example: If apples cost $2 each, then 1 apple = $2, 2 apples = $4, 3 apples = $6. You ALWAYS multiply the number of apples by 2 to get the cost!
key_concepts.visual_description: Think of it like a recipe that you can make bigger or smaller. If you double all ingredients, you get double the food. The RATIO stays the same.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: To check if something is proportional, divide one quantity by the other. If you ALWAYS get the same answer, it's proportional!
key_concepts.real_world_example: Gas costs $4 per gallon. 2 gallons = $8 (8Ã·2=4). 5 gallons = $20 (20Ã·5=4). 10 gallons = $40 (40Ã·10=4). Same answer every time = PROPORTIONAL!
key_concepts.visual_description: Imagine you have a table with two columns. Divide each pair. If all your answers match, you have a proportional relationship.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Some relationships seem like they might be proportional, but they're not! Usually these have something added or subtracted, or involve multiplication by itself (like squaring).
key_concepts.real_world_example: A pizza delivery fee is $5 plus $10 per pizza. 1 pizza = $15. 2 pizzas = $25. But 25Ã·2 = 12.5, not 15! The $5 fee messes it up - NOT proportional.
key_concepts.visual_description: If there's a 'starting amount' that doesn't change, it's usually NOT proportional.

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 1: Checking if a relationship is proportional
step_by_step_examples.problem: A movie theater charges $12 per ticket. Is the relationship between number of tickets and total cost proportional?

steps.instruction: Make a table with some values
Divide cost by tickets for each row
Check if all answers are the same

steps.work: YES, this IS a proportional relationship!

step_by_step_examples.answer: Yes, it's proportional because the cost is always 12 times the number of tickets.

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 2: A NON-proportional relationship
step_by_step_examples.problem: A gym membership costs $50 to join plus $20 per month. Is this proportional?

steps.instruction: Make a table with some values
Divide cost by months for each row
Check if all answers are the same

steps.work: NOT proportional because of the $50 joining fee.

step_by_step_examples.answer: No, it's NOT proportional because the $50 joining fee means you don't multiply by the same number each time.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking any relationship with multiplication is proportional
common_mistakes.why_wrong: y = xÂ² uses multiplication, but it's NOT proportional! When x doubles, y quadruples (not doubles).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check: does doubling one quantity double the other? If not, it's not proportional.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to check if zero works
common_mistakes.why_wrong: In a true proportional relationship, when one quantity is 0, the other must be 0 too.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Ask yourself: 'If I have 0 of one thing, do I have 0 of the other?' If not, it's probably not proportional.

sections.encouragement: Great job learning about proportional relationships! This is the foundation for everything else in this unit. Take your time to really understand this before moving on. ðŸŒŸ

sections.title: The Constant of Proportionality (k)

introduction.hook: Remember how we kept dividing and getting the same number? That special number has a name, and it's super important!
introduction.overview: The constant of proportionality is the number you ALWAYS multiply by to go from one quantity to the other. We often call it 'k' in math.

key_concepts.concept: What is the Constant of Proportionality?
key_concepts.simple_explanation: It's the 'magic multiplier' - the number that connects two proportional quantities. You multiply one quantity by k to get the other.
key_concepts.real_world_example: If carpet costs $1.50 per square foot, then 1.50 is the constant of proportionality. You multiply square feet Ã— 1.50 to get the cost.
key_concepts.visual_description: Think of k as a machine: you put in one number, multiply by k, and out comes the other number. Always the same k!

key_concepts.simple_explanation: To find k, just divide! Pick any row in your table and divide: k = y Ã· x (or output Ã· input).
key_concepts.real_world_example: If 4 hours of work earns $60, then k = 60 Ã· 4 = 15. So k = 15 (that's $15 per hour).
key_concepts.visual_description: k is the answer you get when you divide y by x in any row of a proportional relationship table.

key_concepts.concept: What k Means in Real Life
key_concepts.simple_explanation: The constant of proportionality is often a RATE - like dollars per item, miles per hour, or cups per batch.
key_concepts.real_world_example: If k = 1.50 for carpet, it means '$1.50 per square foot.' If k = 65 for driving, it means '65 miles per hour.'
key_concepts.visual_description: k often answers the question 'how much of one thing per one of the other?'

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 1: Finding k from a table
step_by_step_examples.problem: Find the constant of proportionality: Square feet: 10, 20, 50 â†’ Cost: $15, $30, $75

steps.instruction: Pick any pair from the table
Divide: k = cost Ã· square feet
Check with another pair to make sure

steps.work: k = 1.5 means the carpet costs $1.50 per square foot

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 2: Using k to find missing values
step_by_step_examples.problem: If k = 1.5, how much does 80 square feet of carpet cost?

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 3: Finding k from a word problem
step_by_step_examples.problem: A recipe uses 2 cups of peach juice for every 5 cups of grape juice. What is k?

steps.instruction: Write as a fraction (peach Ã· grape)

steps.work: For every 1 cup of grape juice, you need 0.4 cups of peach juice

common_mistakes.why_wrong: k = y Ã· x (not x Ã· y). The order matters! Getting it backwards gives you 1/k instead of k.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always think: 'What am I trying to find per what?' Cost per square foot means cost Ã· square feet.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking k must be a whole number
common_mistakes.why_wrong: k can be any number! It can be a fraction (like 1/4), a decimal (like 3.14), or a whole number (like 5).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Don't round unless told to. Fractions and decimals are perfectly fine for k.

sections.encouragement: You're doing awesome! Finding k is like finding a secret code that unlocks the relationship. Once you have k, you can find ANY value in the relationship! ðŸ”‘

sections.title: Writing Equations for Proportional Relationships

introduction.hook: Now that you know about k, let's turn these relationships into equations! Equations are like shortcuts - instead of making a huge table, you write one line that works for ANY value.
introduction.overview: All proportional relationships can be written as y = kx, where k is the constant of proportionality.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Every proportional relationship follows this pattern: y equals k times x. That's it! y = kx
key_concepts.real_world_example: If candy costs $3 each: cost = 3 Ã— number of candies. Using letters: c = 3n (where c = cost, n = number)
key_concepts.visual_description: y = kx means: output = (constant) Ã— input. It's a multiplication machine!

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Instead of always using x and y, use letters that make sense! Use the first letter of what you're measuring.
key_concepts.real_world_example: For carpet cost: c = 1.5f (c for cost, f for square feet). For distance and time: d = 65t (d for distance, t for time)
key_concepts.visual_description: Good variable names help you remember what the equation is about.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: An equation is proportional if it's JUST multiplication: y = (some number) Ã— x. Nothing added, nothing subtracted, no powers.
key_concepts.real_world_example: Proportional: y = 4x, d = 1/3t, c = 0.99n. NOT proportional: y = 4 + x, A = sÂ², y = 36/x
key_concepts.visual_description: If you see + or - or Â² in the equation, it's probably NOT proportional.

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 1: Writing an equation from words
step_by_step_examples.problem: Each square foot of carpet costs $1.50. Write an equation relating cost and square feet.

steps.work: Let c = cost in dollars, f = square feet

steps.instruction: Write the equation using y = kx format

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 2: Writing an equation from a recipe
step_by_step_examples.problem: For every 5 cups of grape juice, mix in 2 cups of peach juice. Write an equation with p for peach and g for grape.

steps.instruction: Find the relationship as a rate
steps.work: 2 cups peach per 5 cups grape = 2/5 per cup of grape

steps.instruction: Check: if g = 5, what is p?

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 3: Identifying which equations are proportional
step_by_step_examples.problem: Which of these represent proportional relationships? a) K = C + 273  b) s = (1/4)p  c) V = sÂ³  d) p = 0.4g

steps.work: Just multiplication by 1/4. This IS proportional! k = 1/4
sÂ³ means s Ã— s Ã— s. This is a power, NOT proportional.
Just multiplication by 0.4. This IS proportional! k = 0.4

common_mistakes.mistake: Adding extra stuff to the equation
common_mistakes.why_wrong: y = 3x + 2 is NOT proportional because of the + 2. Proportional equations ONLY have multiplication.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Your equation should look like y = (number)x with nothing else. Just one letter, one number, and a multiplication.

common_mistakes.mistake: Confusing which variable is x and which is y
common_mistakes.why_wrong: If you mix them up, your k will be upside down (you'll get 1/k instead of k).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: The variable you multiply BY k is x (the input). The variable that EQUALS something is y (the output).

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking y = x/3 is different from y = (1/3)x
common_mistakes.why_wrong: They're the same! Dividing by 3 is the same as multiplying by 1/3. Both have k = 1/3.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: dividing by a number is the same as multiplying by its reciprocal.

sections.encouragement: You're turning into an equation-writing machine! ðŸ¤– Remember, equations are just a quick way to describe a relationship. Once you write one, you can find ANY value you need!

sections.title: Graphing Proportional Relationships

introduction.hook: Graphs are like pictures of relationships! When you graph a proportional relationship, something magical happens - you always get a perfectly straight line through the origin!
introduction.overview: Proportional relationships create straight lines that pass through the point (0, 0) - called the origin.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: When you plot points from a proportional relationship and connect them, you get a straight line. This line ALWAYS goes through (0, 0).
key_concepts.real_world_example: If you graph carpet cost vs. square feet, and 0 sq ft costs $0, 10 sq ft costs $15, 20 sq ft costs $30... these points form a straight line through the origin.
key_concepts.visual_description: Imagine drawing a line from the corner of the graph (0,0) straight up and to the right. That's what a proportional relationship looks like!

key_concepts.simple_explanation: The origin (0, 0) MUST be on the line because: if you have 0 of one thing, you have 0 of the other. Zero times anything is zero!
key_concepts.real_world_example: 0 square feet of carpet costs $0. 0 hours of work = $0 pay. 0 candies cost $0. Makes sense, right?
key_concepts.visual_description: If a line doesn't go through (0, 0), the relationship is NOT proportional.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: You can find k by picking ANY point on the line and dividing: k = y Ã· x. You can also look at the 'steepness' (slope) of the line.
key_concepts.real_world_example: If the point (10, 15) is on the line, then k = 15 Ã· 10 = 1.5
key_concepts.visual_description: Steeper lines have bigger k values. Flatter lines have smaller k values.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: To graph a proportional relationship: 1) Make a table of values, 2) Plot each point (x, y), 3) Connect with a straight line through (0, 0).
key_concepts.real_world_example: For the grape/peach juice recipe (5 grape â†’ 2 peach): Plot (0,0), (5,2), (10,4), (15,6). Connect the dots!
key_concepts.visual_description: Think of it like connect-the-dots, but the dots are always in a straight line.

steps.work: x-axis: square feet (0 to 50), y-axis: cost in dollars (0 to 70)
Plot the origin: 0 sq ft costs $0

step_by_step_examples.title: Example 3: Is this graph proportional?
step_by_step_examples.problem: A graph shows a straight line, but it passes through (0, 5) instead of (0, 0). Is it proportional?

steps.work: NOT proportional - even though it's straight, it doesn't go through the origin

step_by_step_examples.answer: No, it's NOT proportional because it doesn't pass through (0, 0)

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Even if (0, 0) isn't in your table, it MUST be on the line for proportional relationships.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always start by plotting (0, 0), then add your other points.

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Proportional relationships are ALWAYS straight lines. If your points don't line up straight, check your math!
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Use a ruler! If points don't line up, you made a calculation error somewhere.

common_mistakes.mistake: Mixing up x and y coordinates
common_mistakes.why_wrong: (10, 15) means x=10, y=15. Swapping them gives the wrong point!
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: (x, y) means (horizontal, vertical). Go right first, then up.

sections.encouragement: Graphs are super powerful! ðŸ“Š Now you can SEE relationships, not just calculate them. Plus, you can use a graph to estimate values that aren't in your table!

sections.title: Circles: Circumference

introduction.hook: Circles are everywhere - wheels, pizzas, clocks, coins! Let's learn how to measure around a circle. This might surprise you, but it's actually a proportional relationship!
introduction.overview: The circumference (distance around a circle) is always Ï€ times the diameter. This makes circumference and diameter proportional!

key_concepts.simple_explanation: A circle has special parts with special names: the center (middle point), radius (center to edge), diameter (edge to edge through center), and circumference (distance around).
key_concepts.real_world_example: On a bicycle wheel: the axle is at the center, a spoke is like a radius, and the tire is the circumference.
key_concepts.visual_description: Radius is like a spoke going from the center to the edge. Diameter is like a spoke that goes ALL the way across, passing through the center.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: The diameter is TWICE the radius. Or: the radius is HALF the diameter. d = 2r, or r = d/2
key_concepts.real_world_example: If a pizza has a radius of 6 inches (center to crust), its diameter is 12 inches (crust to crust through center).
key_concepts.visual_description: Think of diameter as two radii (radiuses) placed end to end.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Pi is a special number (approximately 3.14) that shows up whenever you work with circles. The circumference divided by the diameter ALWAYS equals pi!
key_concepts.real_world_example: Take ANY circle - a quarter, a frisbee, Earth! - and divide its circumference by its diameter. You'll always get about 3.14!
key_concepts.visual_description: Ï€ â‰ˆ 3.14159... It goes on forever, but we usually just use 3.14 or the Ï€ button on a calculator.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: C = Ï€d (Circumference = pi times diameter) or C = 2Ï€r (Circumference = 2 times pi times radius). Both work!
key_concepts.real_world_example: A bike wheel with diameter 26 inches: C = Ï€ Ã— 26 â‰ˆ 3.14 Ã— 26 â‰ˆ 81.64 inches around.
key_concepts.visual_description: The circumference is a little more than 3 times the diameter. If you rolled a circle on a ruler, it would travel about 3.14 diameters.

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Using radius in the diameter formula (or vice versa) gives an answer that's off by a factor of 2.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check: diameter goes ALL the way across through the center. Radius is only HALF of that.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to multiply by 2 when using radius
common_mistakes.why_wrong: C = Ï€r is WRONG! You need C = 2Ï€r when using radius.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: C = Ï€d OR C = 2Ï€r. If you use r, don't forget the 2!

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the wrong value for Ï€
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Ï€ is not exactly 3! Using 3 instead of 3.14 will make your answers too small.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Use 3.14 (or your calculator's Ï€ button) unless told otherwise.

sections.encouragement: You've unlocked the secrets of circles! ðŸ”µ Pi is one of the coolest numbers in all of math. It shows up everywhere in nature and science!

sections.title: Circles: Area

introduction.hook: Now that you know how to measure AROUND a circle, let's learn to measure INSIDE! How much pizza is in that pizza? How much grass is in that circular garden?
introduction.overview: The area of a circle equals pi times the radius squared: A = Ï€rÂ²

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Area is the amount of space INSIDE a shape. It's measured in square units (like square inches or square centimeters).
key_concepts.real_world_example: The area of a pizza tells you how much pizza you actually get to eat. The area of a rug tells you how much floor it covers.
key_concepts.visual_description: Imagine filling the inside of a circle with tiny squares. That's what area measures!

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Area of a circle = pi times radius times radius. You MUST use the radius (not diameter), and you MUST square it!
key_concepts.real_world_example: A pizza with radius 6 inches: A = Ï€ Ã— 6Â² = Ï€ Ã— 36 â‰ˆ 113.04 square inches of pizza!
key_concepts.visual_description: rÂ² means r Ã— r. So A = Ï€ Ã— r Ã— r.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: Squaring makes sense because area is two-dimensional (length Ã— width). Even though circles are round, we're still measuring a flat space.
key_concepts.real_world_example: If you double the radius of a circle, the area becomes 4 times bigger (not 2 times). That's because of the squaring!
key_concepts.visual_description: Imagine cutting a circle into pizza slices and rearranging them into an almost-rectangle. The 'width' is the radius, and the 'length' is half the circumference.

key_concepts.simple_explanation: If you're given diameter, first find the radius by dividing by 2. Then use A = Ï€rÂ².
key_concepts.real_world_example: A table with diameter 4 feet: radius = 4 Ã· 2 = 2 feet. Area = Ï€ Ã— 2Â² = Ï€ Ã— 4 â‰ˆ 12.56 square feet.
key_concepts.visual_description: Diameter â†’ divide by 2 â†’ radius â†’ square it â†’ multiply by Ï€ â†’ area!

common_mistakes.mistake: Using diameter instead of radius in A = Ï€rÂ²
common_mistakes.why_wrong: If you use diameter, your answer will be 4 times too big!
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: ALWAYS check: did they give you radius or diameter? If diameter, divide by 2 first!

common_mistakes.why_wrong: A = Ï€r is WRONG for area! That's closer to circumference. Area uses rÂ².
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: Area = Ï€ times r SQUARED. Write out A = Ï€ Ã— r Ã— r if it helps.

common_mistakes.why_wrong: A = (Ï€r)Â² is wrong! It's A = Ï€ Ã— (rÂ²). Square the radius first, then multiply by Ï€.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Do operations in order: 1) Square r, 2) Multiply by Ï€.

common_mistakes.mistake: Mixing up area and circumference formulas
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Area (inside) = Ï€rÂ². Circumference (around) = 2Ï€r or Ï€d. They're different!
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Area has a square (rÂ²) because it measures square units. Circumference doesn't.
